discussion.content: This question is on the exam.
The answer to this question should be A. The Cut command in D is incorrect. It should use the -d flag to define a delimiter, not F (which is fields).
A is correct. I have conducted a test just like JEDDAWy.
@BigBo1010 thanks for everything this is helpfull whta you are doing. it did help me a lot on the exam. tks
I have just conducted a test, and A is the correct answer. the command in D is incorrect as highlighted by Blind_Hatred.

choices.B: cat authlog.log | grep "2016-01-01" | echo "valid username found: $2"

comments.content:
https://ethicalhackingblog.com/uncovering-hidden-ssids/

Even though the SSID is hidden and not broadcasted, whenever a legitimate client tries to connect to the access point, they exchange probe request and probe response packets. These packets contain the SSID of the access point. As these packets are not encrypted, they can be very easily sniffed from the air and the SSID can be found.

In many cases, all clients may be already connected to the access point and there may be no probe request/response packets available in the Wireshark trace. Here, we can forcibly disconnect the clients from the access point by sending forged deauthentication packets on the air. These packets will force the clients to reconnect back to the access point, thus revealing the SSID.
The question mentions that the analyst is performing a "stealth" black box audit. Forcibly deauthorizing users is not what I would consider stealthy
How does one "Deauthorize" ??? I don't even know what the SSID is...

discussion.content: @ITeaGuy SSID is basically the name of your WIFI network, Deauthorizing is basically telling the AP to disconnect the target from the network on the target's behalf, the target gets disconnected whenever he tries to connect again the SSID will be displayed.

questions.question_text: A security analyst is performing a stealth black-box audit of the local WiFi network and is running a wireless sniffer to capture local WiFi network traffic from a specific wireless access point. The SSID is not appearing in the sniffing logs of the local wireless network traffic. Which of the following is the best action that should be performed NEXT to determine the SSID?

choices.A: Set up a fake wireless access point
choices.B: Power down the wireless access point
choices.D: Spoof the MAC addresses of adjacent access points
choices.C: Deauthorize users of that access point

questions.question_text: A security analyst has performed various scans and found vulnerabilities in several applications that affect production data. Remediation of all exploits may cause certain applications to no longer work. Which of the following activities would need to be conducted BEFORE remediation?

discussion.content: The answer is Correct, Sandbox is supposed to test malware in an isolated environment for analyzing the bahavior. Or maybe for testing an application before going live.
I think it should be D. Sandbox is a testing environment and you should test the remediation if it will cause certain applications to no longer work.
Why wouldn’t I test in a sandbox if the remediations can cause apps to stop working??

comments.content: Because the questions asks what you will do BEFORE remediation. After you have remediated you could then test in a sandbox
Lol. You are going to test in a sandbox AFTER you have remediated? xD
I think the sandbox is not aimed at testing remediations because it is not malicious. I could just crash does not mean we have to run it in the sandbox. I guess Change control is our answer here

questions.question_text: A cybersecurity analyst is investigating an incident report concerning a specific user workstation. The workstation is exhibiting high CPU and memory usage, even when first started, and network bandwidth usage is extremely high. The user reports that applications crash frequently, despite the fact that no significant changes in work habits have occurred. An antivirus scan reports no known threats. Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for this?

discussion.content: the only thing pointing it to an Zero-day is that it was "undetected" by scans. I'll go with Zero-day

comments.content: I agree with you but in most cases, with ATP they mention a data breach or this process started a long time ago , bla bla . Zero-day could be a malicious actor but not that smart. I can bypass the antivirus just because it is not recorded before. ATP is organized and much smarter attack
and also with APT, they tend to go unnoticed for sometime, and wouldn't do anything as much as to create this kind of noise which is very visible to analysts

discussion.content: The incident responders should have this information. While it's technically not a bad idea for management to have this information as well, Security Operations should have this information for sure.

comments.content:
A line from my book:

"Stakeholders
The term stakeholder is broad and could include a very large set of people. For the purposes of the CySA+ exam, what we call IR stakeholders are those individuals and teams who are part of your organization and have a role in helping with some aspects of some incident response. They each have a critical role to play in some (maybe even most) but not all responses."

That said, the term "stakeholder" confuses me. Stakeholder usually mean someone who is not directly involved in the Incident Response process but do have a hand in helping where need be. CySA only defines a couple of these stakeholders: Legal, Marketing, Management and HR.

questions.question_text: During a tabletop exercise, it is determined that a security analyst is required to ensure patching and scan reports are available during an incident, as well as documentation of all critical systems. To which of the following stakeholders should the analyst provide the reports?
